questiontext.text:
Suppose that we have the following three facts.

  1. Alice will be admitted to university only if she is clever.
  2. If Alice is clever then she does not need to work hard
  3. Alice has to work hard.

By forming a chain of logical implications, which of the following is the final conclusion that we can deduce from these statements?

generalfeedback.text:
Set \(A, B\) and \(C\) to be the statements:

  • A: Alice is admitted to university.
  • B: Alice is clever.
  • C: Alice works hard.

Then statement 1. says \(A\) implies \(B\), statement 2. says \(B\) implies \(C\) is false (called the complement of C, often denoted \(\bar{C}\)). Statement 3. tells us that \(C\) is true. Therefore \[ C \mbox{ implies } \bar{B} \qquad \mbox{and} \qquad \bar{B} \mbox{ implies } \bar{A}. \] Therefore we can deduce that Alice will not be admitted to university.

answer.text: Alice will not be admitted into university.
Alice will be admitted into university
